Award.AwardTitle: RAPID COVID-19: Metasurface Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy Platform for High-Sensitivity, Multiplexed Detection of Antibodies and RNA for Point-of-Care Diagnostics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The ability to rapidly and accurately detect coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is imperative in managing the current global outbreak. In response to this critical need, the research groups of Prof. Tao and Prof. Steinmetz at the University of California, San Diego will collaborate to develop sensitive diagnostic tests that are easy to perform at the point-of-care. The project aims to enable 1) direct detection of viral ribonucleic acid (RNA) without the need of RNA amplification; and 2) a sensitive immunoassay at the earlier stages of infection. This project provides interdisciplinary research training opportunities to a postdoctoral researcher, undergraduates, and graduate students. In addition, it promotes teaching and learning by incorporating novel insights from this research into the NanoEngineering undergraduate and graduate curriculum and summarizing the findings in lay terms in videos.<br/><br/>The research team seeks to develop an innovative metasurface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (mSERS) sensing platform for detecting coronavirus infection. Nanoscale optical cavities are uniquely designed to enhance the sensitivity of optical detection by increasing both the local optical field strengths of hot spots and the hot spot area for sampling a large number of analyte molecules in the cavity. The quantitative readout of Raman scattering intensity for a single vibrational band can be performed using a commercial benchtop spectrometer. Integration of this highly sensitive mSERS optical technique with vertical flow, lateral flow, or dipstick devices enables fast, straightforward sample preparation and easy-to-perform testing. This versatile platform can be used for multiplex detection of nucleic acid (RNA and DNA), antigens/antibodies, or biomarkers.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to rapidly detect and diagnose coronavirus disease 2019 ("COVID-19") has been imperative in managing the current global outbreak. However, rapid detection has been hindered by the relatively few point-of-care ("POC") blood tests, which typically lack the sensitivity required for clinical accuracy. This main outcome of this interdisciplinary research project was the development of a point-of-care test based on a unique optical technique called metasurface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy ("mSERS") that is capable of providing the high sensitivities needed for rapid and accurate diagnostics.

 

The intellectual merit of this project was the fabrication of nanostructured materials for both the mSERS platform as well as the testbed viral systems designed to validate the mSERS platform. One major outcome of this work was the design of a simple flow assay for the mSERS platform that can be performed in the clinic using benchtop instrumentation. The flow assay uses specialized metal nanoparticles that, when a specific molecule is present, bind to the mSERS platform to achieve a quantitative optical readout that is indicative of molecular concentration. A second major outcome of this work was the development of a nanoparticle probe that makes nucleic acid test for COVID-19 more accurate and helps to avoid false negatives. The probe is a harmless plant virus that encapsulates snippets of SARS-CoV-2 genome. These snippets of the genome are non-hazardous and non-infectious; thus, the probe is safe for personnel and lab workers.

 

The research outcomes of this work will have broad impact in medical diagnostics, specifically when new detection platforms are required in rapid response to novel diseases such as COVID-19. This work has also had broader impact in how to address an urgent need through biosensing research, as well as in training and education of post-doctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary and collaborative environment.
